purpose: Coordinate consensus development, and discuss consensus-related issues
text: <@U0XQ35CDD|kostas> set the channel purpose: Coordinate consensus development, and discuss consensus-related issues
Yes, I think we need some official cutoff point for the openchain slack, not sure who is checking which
well, we can start talking here
jyellick: is there any issue I should work on?

Hi, I'm using PBFT. I somehow manage to run Fabric on Docker swarm, means, I can scale up/down nodes on the fly.

BTW, I have a question. Is it possible to join a new VP after the existing nodes already have blocks?

E.g.
1. I start with 4 VPs (vp1, vp2, vp3, vp4).
2. Deploy chaincode, all 4 VPs create a new image and run create a new chaincode attaches to itself.
3. Pump transactions, all 4 VPs update its chain.
4. Join a new node as vp5, all existing 4 VPs know the newly join node, discovery list got updated, all 5 VPs connection seemed to be fine.

**Problem**
Any new transaction, will not affect to the vp5, but only old 4VPs.
BTW, I can also send transaction to vp5, but it will pass all thre transaction to the rest 4 VPs.
<@U1T95QCUE>, currently you cannot dynamically add a node to a pbft network.  There's ongoing discussion on this topic in the architecture wg so do join
also,  folks working on consensus use the <#C0Z4NBUN6|fabric-consensus-dev>  channel rather than this one.
Actually I'm working on this scalable consensus node, but with current PBFT, we are stuck on this. BTW, thanks <@U0UGH3X7X> , I'm going to join the channel.
not really related to hyperledger, but ... <http://buhrmi.de/post/150299260509/quest-for-consensus-open-source-hashgraph>

attachments.title: Quest for Consensus: Open Source Hashgraph
attachments.text: It’s been a while since I blogged anything interesting. A new white paper created by Leemon Baird titled “THE SWIRLDS HASHGRAPH CONSENSUS ALGORITHM:FAIR, FAST, BYZANTINE FAULT TOLERANCE” has captured my interest. As far as I can tell, the technology described in the paper has the potential to completely deprecate all block chains in existence. However, currently the only implementation of this technology is written in Java and is not open source, and is only usable with licensing agreements. I would like to create an open source implementation of Hashgraph and the Hashgraph consensus based on javascript. And I’m also looking for some help to do it because I think an openly accessible network based on hashgraph technology can solve some real problems. But why, and how? Well, currently all openly accessible blockchain networks that maintain some sort of consensus over the state of a distributed ledger require some sort of proof-of-x, with “x” being one of “work”, “stake”, “elapased time”, etc. Unfortunately, all these networks come with some kind of disadvantage. A “proof-of-work”-based network encourages participants to burn more energy and find more and more efficient methods to calculate some arbitrary hashes. All this energy is taken from our planet which is already heating up quickly. I’ve been proposing to immediately cease all efforts that goes into the development of “proof-of-work” based networks for a long time, but never wrote about it. So now I’m writing about it. Please stop. A “proof-of-stake”-based network can only work if the participants of the network are also registered somewhere else, some kind of central authority, or certificate authority that authorizes the participants to contribute to the network. There are also blockchain networks that use neither of that, but these are only run on private networks. With Open Source Hashgraph I’d like to provide a new network and new “x”: A “proof-of-trust”-based network. So what does proof-of-trust even mean? It means that anyone is free to participate in the network as long as they have trust in basic math. By participating in the network, you automatically have shown “proof-of-trust”. In the white paper it is mathematically shown that all nodes that participate in the network eventually reach a consensus with probability 1. That’s a mathematical certainty. So with a public and global network, it should be possible to bring the entire world to a consensus. So what is in it for you? Assume you’re working on a project that requires some sort of consensus among multiple computers (eg. replicated state machines, log replication, stock exchanges, etc.). Wouldn’t it be nice if you could simply do this:hashgraph = require('hashgraph');hashgraph.join(someIpAddress);hashgraph.sendTransaction('transfer 5 dollars from peter to stefan')hashgraph.on('consensus', function(transactions) { myApplication.runTransactions(transaction)}) And by doing this you know that the order of transactions will be exactly the same on all nodes that participate in the network, completely immutable, recorded forever and completely for free, and does NOT heat up our planet event more by burning energy to find some dumb hashes. That’s what the hashgraph technology provides. Of course, users would submit application-specific transactions. The string transfer 5 dollars... can be replaced with some binary sequence, signed with a private key. So that anyone can send signed transactions into the hashgraph and build applications on top of it. This is more or less the use-case that I want to cover with an open source hashgraph implementation. I’m currently trying to implement the pseudo-code found in the whitepaper in javascript (current progress here: <http://github.com/buhrmi/hashgraph> Note: It’s not even close to functional), but I’m kinda stuck right now. I’d like to raise some money to hire Leemon Baird to help me (assuming he’s interested, haha). If you also think that this can be usefull and you or your company has some resources to put behind this, please get in touch.
attachments.fallback: /whatever: Quest for Consensus: Open Source Hashgraph

text: Hello I hope this is the right channel to post my question. I am trying to understand *when* a block is created. The spec (<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/protocol-spec.md#3473-committing-and-rolling-back-transactions>) talks about `CommitTxBatch` but it's not clear at what point transactions are bundled to create a block. Also, what prevents a same node from creating blocks always?
Very nice demo of the Gossip protocol has been placed on the <#C28M6TC90|playbacks> channel

Quick question about PBFT - would anyone be able to explain on what grounds the validating leader is changed? (i.e. is it every block, after a certain number of TXs etc.)

Following from this how is the new leader chosen?
Hi <@U2RMVHMK9> , we're using <#C0Z4NBUN6|fabric-consensus-dev> for consensus issues
Does someone experimented this endless loop on PBFT ?
vp0_1         | 09:31:16.098 [consensus/pbft] recvViewChange -> WARN b3c Replica 0 already has a view change message for view 2 from replica 0
I have have all my peers sending the same warning
also the initiator of chaincode deployment  named  "vp0"

what's the view # of the other peers? it seems vp0 is with view 1 and the other peers' view number is higher than 1 so that vp0 view change doesn't succeed and resend viewChange requests all the time. I met the same issue...
<@U1B9E51R8> actually is a simple scenario : 4 peers + 1 CA on v0.6.1-preview   , first deployment of Java Chaincode fails
did you check the peer logs the see each peer's view number?

vp0_1         | 09:31:16.098 [consensus/pbft] recvViewChange -> WARN b3c Replica 0 already has a view change message for view 2 from replica 0
vp2_1         | 09:31:16.098 [consensus/pbft] recvViewChange -> WARN 527 Replica 2 already has a view change message for view 2 from replica 0
vp1_1         | 09:31:16.098 [consensus/pbft] recvViewChange -> WARN 516 Replica 1 already has a view change message for view 2 from replica 0
vp3_1         | 09:31:16.097 [consensus/pbft] recvViewChange -> WARN 52d Replica 3 already has a view change message for view 2 from replica 0
<@U1B9E51R8> weird, they all say the same
they should receive the same message.. replica 0 broadcasts to the other peers to make a view change to view 2, but it seems the other peers don't agree
<@U0N4D2T61> if you simply restart any peer other than replica 0, that should "unblock" replica 0.
This is not an issue of PBFT - it is the way it works

<@U0Y14MWA2> Well this conforts me in the way now I know this is not an issue, but on the other side I do not understand why. Could you explain it in 4 lines max or send me a link easily understandable for me to figure out ?  Thanks in advance  :slightly_smiling_face:
replica 0 for some reason suspected the leader and declared it wants a view change
they stay in that same view
this is a non-straightforward fix as replica 0 could as well be Byzantine - so we cannot change view simply
the solution involves changing the PBFT protocol and introducing gradual entrance to the view change
this is a very invasive change and will not be done for v0.6
why do you mean by "some reason" ?
a chaincode deplyment is the reason of the view change
that should not be the case
well, all node runs on the same server by using docker-compose
i have this behavior at each starts
also I do not understand why a peer restart resolves it
summarizing pbft in slack is not easy
this is a nice weekend reading
but you should not be seeing view change on every chaincode deploy
this is sth that is not a feature
so the workaround is to restart 1 peer
do I will have same problem with Sieve too ?
for V1, SPFT will replace PBFT ?
for v1 we will have a somewhat simplified version of PBFT - dubbed for the moment sBFT
along with support for crash-tolerant consensus based on kafka/zookeeper
ok, thank you so much for the info Marko
sure - no pb - hope that helped a bit

Some quick questions about the Hyperledger v1 proposal:

When we say endorsers check code is 'deterministic' and 'stable', what does this mean?

Doesn't channelling transactions mean the consenters will have different ledgers If not, how are ledgers exchanged between consenters?  How are they kept in sync?

When we say consenters 'validate the integrity' of the transaction, what does this mean?

Why does having a consenters increase transaction throughput, was the previous throughput limit constraint solely due to it needing to speak to all the nodes?

Do both endorsers and consenters have a copy of the ledger, who stores it?
Would anyone be able to help?
<@U2DHRR4TE> I think the developers you should ask are on fabric-consensus-dev channel now.  you may want to post your questions there.

Hi. I have a question on the behavior of synchronization and the checkpoint. I am using Fabric v0.6.0, and 4 nodes,     - CORE_PEER_VALIDATOR_CONSENSUS_PLUGIN=pbft
    - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_K=10
    - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_BATCHSIZE=1
We were testing the synchronization behavior when one of the four node gets down for a while and restarted and back to the network again. In this case, the height of the restarted node is behind that of other nodes. User sent 60 transactions and the node started synchronization and completed synchronization. The user continued sending transactions, but the height of the restarted node did not grow. After sending 120 transactions, the node synchronized again. This sequence pattern was repeated at 60th, 120th, 180th, ... transaction after the restart.
My questions are: 1. Why the synchronization occurs at 60xN-th transactions? 2. Why the restarted node does not accept new transactions after it was synchronized?
and , how can we predict the timing of synchronization from the value of K, or the batch size? I expected that the checkpoint occurs at K=10 transactions and synchronized at that timing ...
Any information or link or comments are welcome. Thank you.
<@U1FBDMBMG>  have you set the viewchangeperiod to 6? this settings is to decide at n*checkpoint, the synchronization occurs.
thank you <@U2CBG8V9U> . We have not set viewchangeperiod explicitly. So the default value in consensus/pbft/config.yaml should be used, I guess. ( viewchangeperiod: 0 )

<@U1FBDMBMG> the syschronization happens only when view changes. The restarted node is not the same view as the other nodes, so it will not synchronize. Since the viewchangepeiod is 0, view changes only happens when one of the other 3 nodes fails, then the viewchagne starts and the synchronization begins. In my guess, when you send 60 transactions, one of the other fine nodes went down, and viewchange occurs and everybody catched up. I am just not sure why this round number, becuase as far as the sourcecode reveals, there is no such settup.
after restarting one node, you can try to stop one of the other three, then you will notice that the restarted one will synchronize

<@U2CBG8V9U> Thank you for the information. In other test cases, I also observed that the synchronization begins when the second node failed, and I was wondering why this happens. Now I can understand that this is related to the viewchange, as you explained. I will check the log again and confirm that those parameters are set as we designed.
I made a little progress on the synchronization problem. I tested with K=1,2,10 and logmultiplier=2,3.
In Experiment 1, send 2 TXs, stop vp0 (primary==leader), send 2 TXs, restart vp0, and send N TXs.

It seemed that the first synchronization occurs at n0 + K*(logmultiplier + 2) - 1, and then repeats synchronization with a period K*(logmultiplier + 2), and vp0 never came back to the normal operation.
So, in  the case of K=10 and logmultiplier=4, the period becomes 60, as reported on Dec.20th in this channel.

Hi. I have a question on the behavior of synchronization and the checkpoint. I am using Fabric v0.6.0, and 4 nodes,     - CORE_PEER_VALIDATOR_CONSENSUS_PLUGIN=pbft
    - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_K=10
    - CORE_PBFT_GENERAL_BATCHSIZE=1
We were testing the synchronization behavior when one of the four node gets down for a while and restarted and back to the network again. In this case, the height of the restarted node is behind that of other nodes. User sent 60 transactions and the node started synchronization and completed synchronization. The user continued sending transactions, but the height of the restarted node did not grow. After sending 120 transactions, the node synchronized again. text: And I saw some WARN message in the log.

vp0_1        | 01:27:42.250 [consensus/pbft] recvCommit -> WARN 0bc Replica 0 ignoring commit for view=1/seqNo=8: not in-wv, in view 0, high water mark 2
vp0_1        | 01:27:42.304 [consensus/pbft] recvCheckpoint -> WARN 0c5 Checkpoint sequence number outside watermarks: seqNo 8, low-mark 2
vp0_1        | 01:27:42.317 [consensus/pbft] weakCheckpointSetOutOfRange -> WARN 0cd Replica 0 is out of date, f+1 nodes agree checkpoint with seqNo 8 exists but our high water mark is 6
vp0_1        | 01:27:42.318 [consensus/pbft] sendPrePrepare -> WARN 0d5 Primary 0 not sending pre-prepare for batch aXZf/Zfi7CDLU5n5dANOpYIX81Oy0LuTZ2mX/Xly48d5yYaULtX+ndFIVKweQ/xej17JXRwkTIV0RiT1j+xKeA== - out of sequence numbers
vp0_1        | 01:27:47.356 [consensus/pbft] sendPrePrepare -> WARN 10d Primary 0 not sending pre-prepare for batch Tq+y1NuMKGw8eJjimsdRecr4RseJ//xE00lkjK+qvg2yK9giQwqCmPnlgCdBBVn/uzxwFsvYn/sHeLcL60O6Dw== - out of sequence numbers
vp0_1        | 01:27:47.357 [consensus/pbft] recvPrePrepare -> WARN 129 Pre-prepare from other than primary: got 1, should be 0
vp0_1        | 01:27:51.361 [consensus/pbft] recvViewChange -> WARN 181 Replica 0 already has a view change message for view 1 from replica 0

I read the PBFT paper by Castro and Liskov (2002) and found the similar description that the state transfer occurs at the first checkpoint which exceeds the high water mark H = log size + h, where log size = K*logmultiplier and h = low water mark, set to the last stable checkpoint. So, it is natural that the state transfer does not occur at the immediate checkpoint, but I still do not understand why the node vp0 does not come back to the normal operation.
From the log message above, I guess that vp0 still believes that he is in view 0, although other nodes in the network is in view 1.
In Experiment 2, send 2 TXs, stop vp2 (backup==non-leader), send 2 TXs, restart vp2, and send N TXs. In this case, no view change required because the leader vp0 is alive throughout the experiment.
Then, I observed that the first synchronization occurred at the same point with Experiment 1, but then vp2 came back to the normal operation and kept synchronized after it was restarted.
So I guess, that there is a some trouble in the view change when the primary node has a failure and come back to the network.

There is gRPC error from orderer when it tries to send the Deploy Transaction Block to Peer. Port exposed by peer by default is 7051. However orderer uses the right docker container IP of Commiter Peer (which is also endorser for 1 Peer Setup) but a different port (48144 and randomly in increasing order). This results in write broken pipe error. How does Orderer know about the list of Committer Peers (IP, Port) on the Hyperledger network, is there a way can provide more debug information or is there a known solution?

Setup: Fabric {peer, cop and orderer} images are used from the connect-a-thon - v1.0 architecture and is currently used to run a custom-helloworld-chaincode  using DEV mode.

Secondly - I have tried this on Linux box hosted on AWS and has never seen this problem however on our internal organization boxes (Intranet one of the environment difference), we see this error almost frequently.
i would go to fabric-consensus-dev channel... most of the developers are sitting on that channel now.

hi everybody, in case you have not heard, linux foundation is moving us off of Slack and onto Rocket.Chat, everybody in Slack can log in to the new chat server using your existing linux foundation ID, please visit <http://chat.hyperledger.org/> to login to the new chat server
